Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned about the internet and basic frameworks for the digital world.
Information Theory, graph theory, how ISBN numbers work. Also some Fourier stuff...kinda.
I learned a lot about networks and important material on processing and transmitting information.
Basics in many fields of electrical engineering: information theory, network theory, signals (fourier transforms), and machine learning (maximum likelihood estimates, hypothesis testing).
Systems and Signals engineering
Signal and Systems, Foundational class and the topic is fascinating and very useful in the Industry.

While the material the you do cover is very interesting, you learn very little in class and mostly by struggling on your own and reading the lectures notes & textbook. You cover a very broad range of topics, ranging from encoding to machine learning, but never end up knowing anything deeply or well enough to confidently list that topic as something you know. Definitely learn a lot on how to write a lot of garbage on a topic you never fully understood and how to pretend you know something when you dont. In terms of actual practical knowledge, you wont get much of it in this course.
information theory, codes, quantization, sampling, signals/systems, fourier, basic ML
I developed a general knowledge of various concepts throughout electrical engineering, but decidedly still lack confidence in actually working through problems.
I learned about information theory, networks, and machine learning.
I learned the broad strokes of encoding and decoding, routing, a lot of probability, etc. The course covered A LOT of material!
Developed matlab skills
Various electrical engineering concepts from many subfields.
I was introduced to the concepts that, for example, make it possible to take a picture and post it online, from quantization to message coding to compression to signals to networking.

I think this course is a difficult course because of the broad list of topics, which require a strong background to understand well.  Coming out of the course, I don't think that I could explain many of the topics, but to solve this, I think there should be more thought into depth vs. breadth.  For example, the few classes on machine learning and security (I know they were supposed to be an introduction to the topic),  were necessary and could have been used for reviewing the prior topics.  Most of the students did not feel confident in the prior topics, and allocating the aforementioned class time to concrete examples would have helped us understand the important topics (like Fourier, convolution, etc.). Nick's office hours definitely helped me get a strong grasp on what we did in class, but I think he should have held more.  Finally, as for the examples used in class, I think they started out too general (especially with the notation), and with the students' backgrounds are factored in, they were too abstract to apply.  More examples with basic wording and a step-by-step walkthrough would have helped tremendously with the psets.

This class would be awesome if in class there were some example questions worked out. 
I found that the classes were incredibly abstract and the PSETs dealt with real-number examples, and it was quite difficult to translate from one to the other.

Strengths:
- I find it great that we review previous material at the beginning of every lecture

Weaknesses:
- I wish the problem sets were not just based on completion.
The strengths are the material (and the matlab labs), it is very interesting and applicable to many different fields in EE. The weakness is probably the teaching, which made lectures very dry.

The content of the class is very interesting the way it is presented to us not so much especially since we can't explore any of the concepts in depth due to a lack of mathematical knowledge such as stats and linear algebra

Strengths: topics are cool, lecture notes are often very complete and the textbook is very engaging.
Weaknesses: THE LECTURES. Wenjun is a nice person, but completely inadequate as a professor. This appear to be a general trend in the EE department - they hire amazing researchers, but horrible lecturers. Most people dont show up to class. Sitting through 75mins of lecture is absolutely excruciating. She is unable to explain things clearly and in an understandable way. Doesnt show enough clear examples that showcase what is expected from us. That becomes quite frustrating, because the topic we cover can get very complex so you can get deep into following a complicated method without realising that she expects us to use simple shortcuts. A very frustrating and annoying class as a whole that made me want to switch my major away from EE.

This course should have coding prerequisites and does not. It expects that you will be able to complete coding-based lab assignments individually, even with no coding background. It should also have a linear algebra prerequisite. On the first day, we were told that this course would not be math intensive, but rather focus on grasping a conceptual understanding of the material. Although this statement generally holds true, students who have a linear algebra background are able to understand the concepts far more easily than those who have not taken a linear algebra class. By not having prerequisites for this course, it puts students at an immediate disadvantage, and this is not clear at the beginning of the course. 

Additionally, the lectures are also taught in a very disorganized fashion that makes it hard to follow and difficult to recognize the bigger picture for the concepts about which we learned. Expect that most of this material will be learned on your own using a textbook. The textbook however is very well written and does provide a good basic understanding of concepts. There are also detailed lecture notes and slides on canvas, but again, a linear algebra understanding is necessary for at least the lecture slides included in the second half of the course.

The course taught high level concepts well but utterly failed to train students on working through problems and actually being able to use their high level knowledge. More time should be spent working through problems in class and psets should be more rigoursly graded to provide greater incentive to actually learn how to do the problems.
The course seems a little too broad. The material itself was enjoyable, but difficult to learn.
I think that we didnt do enough practice/ example problems in the course. It made it incredibly hard to get the bigger picture i.e. what we were actually learning and what it co update be applied to.
Sometimes Wenjun would get stuck trying to explain one topic for most of the lecture.

This course, while its subject matter is intriguing, really doesnt feel like it has a unifying thread. I found it very difficult to appreciate the course material in any context larger than the problem set assigned that week.
Even if she's not the best lecturer, Wenjun tries really hard to be engaging and approachable, which is much appreciated. The online lecture notes are also very helpful.

Strengths: Fascinating material; Homework graded for effort; Not necessary to have taken linear algebra or probability & statistics; Recaps at the beginning of each lesson; Lecture notes posted online; Allowed to bring notes to exams; The Professor and TA explained concepts well; MATLAB assignments were practically fill-in-the-blank but still educational.
Weaknesses: Not enough worked examples, so it was sometimes hard to apply the concepts to homework problems.
I would only recommend if the course organization changed, or if it is required for the major.

If you're an EE or EECS major, it's a course req. So I'd recommend it to them for the sake of getting a degree.
Other than that, not so much.

Yes, because it contains important topics about Electrical Engineering without really knowing how electrical components work. I think it is a good overview course for students considering EE as a major.

I would recommend this to any other EE student, especially if you are early on in your EE/CS career. There are many interesting topics, and although you may need to learn many of the topics more in depth on your own, it will make learning all of these topics again later much easier.
Yes, good intro to Systems and Signals

I would not recommend this class to any student. The content is interesting but we do not really learn about it in depth. A lot of this content can probably be learned better through a book if the student is really interested and has the math to back it up.
Do not recommend this course at all. It completely butchers otherwise very fascinating topics.
The content is great. The teaching is bad, it it's with Professor Hu. I'd say worst taught class at Yale but coolest content in EE, so pick what matters to you.
Yes, but with the caveat that you will need to put a lot of time in reading course materials and self-teaching.
Not unless you have to take it for your major. The course was pretty unorganized and Im not sure how much I actually got out of it in the end.
Dont take it unless its required
Inasmuch as it is a required course, I suppose I would- however, beyond that I would not take it. I am strongly considering changing my major as a result of this course

Even though the course is fairly information dense and Wenjun isn't the best lecturer, I would still recommend this class. She tries her best to make sure everyone is on the same page, so you can't really fault her. The material we covered, however, is very interesting - I learned much more about various facets of electrical engineering that I never even knew were considered part of the field.
I would recommend this course to students interested in learning information theory and the mathematics of electrical systems.
